currentDoc:
How Worried Should We Be About Screen Time During the Pandemic?

The coronavirus pandemic ended the screen time debate: Screens won. We all now find ourselves on our screens for school, for work and for connecting with family and friends during this time of social distancing and increased isolation.

But should we be worried about this excessive screen use right now? Or should we finally get over it and embrace the benefits of our digital devices?

The coronavirus pandemic ended the screen time debate: Screens won. We all now find ourselves on our screens for school, for work and for connecting with family and friends during this time of social distancing and increased isolation.

But should we be worried about this excessive screen use right now? Or should we finally get over it and embrace the benefits of our digital devices?

---

In my opinion, embrace it.  It has become a necessity so there is no point in having guilt, etc. about it.  At some point things will change and our behaviors will be more balanced.

Just think how up the creek without a paddle we would have been if we hadn't had the accessibility to screens and all the things they make possible.  Remote work would have been mostly impossible for many.

But should we be worried about this excessive screen use right now? Or should we finally get over it and embrace the benefits of our digital devices?

---

In my opinion, embrace it.  It has become a necessity so there is no point in having guilt, etc. about it.  At some point things will change and our behaviors will be more balanced.

Just think how up the creek without a paddle we would have been if we hadn't had the accessibility to screens and all the things they make possible.  Remote work would have been mostly impossible for many.  Online shopping impossible.  Keeping up with others would have involved long periods of delay and intimacy would have suffered.  Schooling would have been limited to what is in a book with no ready explanations or fun games to ass

The coronavirus pandemic ended the screen time debate: Screens won. We all now find ourselves on our screens for school, for work and for connecting with family and friends during this time of social distancing and increased isolation.

But should we be worried about this excessive screen use right now? Or should we finally get over it and embrace the benefits of our digital devices?

---

In my opinion, embrace it.  It has become a necessity so there is no point in having guilt, etc. about it.  At some point things will change and our behaviors will be more balanced.

Just think how up the creek without a paddle we would have been if we hadn't had the accessibility to screens and all the things they make possible.  Remote work would have been mostly impossible for many.  Online shopping impossible.  Keeping up with others would have involved long periods of delay and intimacy would have suffered.  Schooling would have been limited to what is in a book with no ready explanations or fun games to assist.   

I think we are in a time of transition.  There should be and will be a bala

Remote work would have been mostly impossible for many.  Online shopping impossible.  Keeping up with others would have involved long periods of delay and intimacy would have suffered.  Schooling would have been limited to what is in a book with no ready explanations or fun games to assist.   

I think we are in a time of transition.  There should be and will be a balance as things normalize once again b

In my opinion, embrace it.  It has become a necessity so there is no point in having guilt, etc. about it.  At some point things will change and our behaviors will be more balanced.

Just think how up the creek without a paddle we would have been if we hadn't had the accessibility to screens and all the things they make possible.  Remote work would have been mostly impossible for many.  Online shopping impossible.  Keeping up with others would have involved long periods of delay and intimacy would have suffered.  Schooling would have been limited to what is in a book with no ready explanations or fun games to assist.   

I think we are in a time of transition.  There should be and will be a balance as things normalize once again but screens are here to stay.  Perhaps w

But should we be worried about this excessive screen use right now? Or should we finally get over it and embrace the benefits of our digital devices?

---

In my opinion, embrace it.  It has become a necessity so there is no point in having guilt, etc. about it.  At some point things will change and our behaviors will be more balanced.

Just think how up the creek without a paddle we would have been if we hadn't had the accessibility to screens and all the things they make possible.  Remote work would have been mostly impossible for many.  Online shopping impossible.  Keeping up with others would have involved long periods of delay and intimacy would have suffered.  Schooling would have been limited to what is in a book with no ready explanations or fun games to assist.   

I think we are in a time of transition.  There should be and will be a balance as things normalize once again but screens are here to stay.  Perhaps we are just concerned about change, c

But should we be worried about this excessive screen use right now? Or should we finally get over it and embrace the benefits of our digital devices?

---

In my opinion, embrace it.  It has become a necessity so there is no point in having guilt, etc. about it.  At some point things will change and our behaviors will be more balanced.

Just think how up the creek without a paddle we would have been if we hadn't had the accessibility to screens and all the things they make possible.  Remote work would have been mostly impossible for many.  Online shopping impossible.  Keeping up with others would have involved long periods of delay and intimacy would have suffered.  Schooling would have been limited to what is in a book with no ready explanations or fun games to assist.   

I think we are in a time of transition.  There should be and will be a balance as things normalize once again but screens are here to stay.  Perhaps we are just concerned about change, change in the way we work, relate to t

Just think how up the creek without a paddle we would have been if we hadn't had the accessibility to screens and all the things they make possible.  Remote work would have been mostly impossible for many.  Online shopping impossible.  Keeping up with others would have involved long periods of delay and intimacy would have suffered.  Schooling would have been limited to what is in a book with no ready explanations or fun games to assist.

How Worried Should We Be About Screen Time During the Pandemic?

The coronavirus pandemic ended the screen time debate: Screens won. We all now find ourselves on our screens for school, for work and for connecting with family and friends during this time of social distancing and increased isolation.

The coronavirus pandemic ended the screen time debate: Screens won. We all now find ourselves on our screens for school, for work and for connecting with family and friends during this time of social distancing and increased isolation.

But should we be worried about this excessive screen use right now? Or should we finally get over it and embrace the benefits of our digital devices?

---

In my opinion, embrace it.  It has become a necessity so there is no point in having guilt, etc. about it.  At some point things will change and our behaviors will be more balanced.

Just think how up the creek without a paddle we would have been if we hadn't had the accessibility to screens and all the things they make possible.  Remote work would have been mostly impossible for many.  Online shopping impossible.  Keeping up with others would have involved long periods of delay and intimacy would have suffered.  Schooling would have been limited to what is in a book with no ready explanations or fun games to assist.   

I think we are in a time of transition.  There should be and will be a balance as things normalize once again but screens are here to stay.  Perhaps we are just concerned about change, change in the way we work, relate to others, conduct ourselves.  Who among us has not just gussied up f

Remote work would have been mostly impossible for many.  Online shopping impossible.  Keeping up with others would have involved long periods of delay and intimacy would have suffered.  Schooling would have been limited to what is in a book with no ready explanations or fun games to assist.   

I think we are in a time of transition.  There should be and will be a balance as things normalize once again but screens are here to stay.  Perhaps we are just concerned about change, change in the way we work, relate to others, conduct ourselves.  Who among us has not just gussied up from the waist up for a Zoom caa

Just think how up the creek without a paddle we would have been if we hadn't had the accessibility to screens and all the things they make possible.  Remote work would have been mostly impossible for many.  Online shopping impossible.  Keeping up with others would have involved long periods of delay and intimacy would have suffered.  Schooling would have been limited to what is in a book with no ready explanations or fun games to assist.   

I think we are in a time of transition.  There should be and will be a balance as things normalize once again but screens are here to stay.  Perhaps we are just concerned about change, change in the way we work, relate to others, conduct ourselves. How Worried Should We Be About Screen Time During the Pandemic?

The coronavirus pandemic ended the screen time debate: Screens won. We all now find ourselves on our screens for school, for work and for connecting with family and friends during this time of social distancing and increased isolation.

But should we be worried about this excessive screen use right now? Or should we finally get over it and embrace the benefits of our digital devices?

---

In my opinion, embrace it.  It has become a necessity so there is no point in having guilt, etc. about it.  At some point things will change and our behaviors will be more balanced.

Just think how up the creek without a paddle we would have been if we hadn't had the accessibility to screens and all the things they make possible.  Remote work would have been mostly impossible for many.  Online shopping impossible.  Keeping up with others would have involved long periods of delay and intimacy would have suffered.  Schooling would have been limited to what is in a book with no ready explanations or fun games to assist.   

I think we are in a time of transition.  There should be and will be a balance as things normalize once again but screens are here to stay.  Perhaps we are just concerned about change, change in the way we work, relate to others, conduct ourselves. How Worried Should We Be About Screen Time During the Pandemic?

The coronavirus pandemic ended the screen time debate: Screens won. We all now find ourselves on our screens for school, for work and for connecting with family and friends during this time of social distancing and increased isolation.

But should we be worried about this excessive screen use right now? Or should we finally get over it and embrace the benefits of our digital devices?

---

In my opinion, embrace it.  It has become a necessity so there is no point in having guilt, etc. about it.  At some point things will change and our behaviors will be more balanced.

Just think how up the creek without a paddle we would have been if we hadn't had the accessibility to screens and all the things they make possible.  Remote work would have been mostly impossible for many.  Online shopping impossible.  Keeping up with others would have involved long periods of delay and intimacy would have suffered.  Schooling would have been limited to what is in a book with no ready explanations or fun games to assist.   

I think we are in a time of transition.  There should be and will be a balance as things normalize once again but screens are here to stay.  Perhaps we are just concerned about change, change in the way we work, relate to others, conduct ourselves.  Who among us has not just gussied up from the waist up for a Zoom call, skipping a shower and matching socks?  We need to establish new norms of behavio

How Worried Should We Be About Screen Time During the Pandemic?

The coronavirus pandemic ended the screen time debate: Screens won. We all now find ourselves on our screens for school, for work and for connecting with family and friends during this time of social distancing and increased isolation.

But should we be worried about this excessive screen use right now? Or should we finally get over it and embrace the benefits of our digital devices?

---

In my opinion, embrace it.  It has become a necessity so there is no point in having guilt, etc. about it.  At some point things will change and our behaviors will be more balanced.

Just think how up the creek without a paddle we would have been if we hadn't had the accessibility to screens and all the things they make possible.  Remote work would have been mostly impossible for many.  Online shopping impossible.  Keeping up with others would have involved long periods of delay and intimacy would have suffered.  Schooling would have been limited to what is in a book with no ready explanations or fun games to assist.   

I think we are in a time of transition.  There should be and will be a balance as things normalize once again but screens are here to stay.  Perhaps we are just concerned about change, change in the way we work, relate to others, conduct ourselves.  Who among us has not just gussied up from the waist up for a Zoom call, skipping a shower and matching socks?  We need to establish new norms of behavior. In my opinion, embrace it.  It has become a necessity so there is no point in having guilt, etc. about it.  At some point things will change and our behaviors will be more balanced.

Just think how up the creek without a paddle we would have been if we hadn't had the accessibility to screens and all the things they make possible.  Remote work would have been mostly impossible for many.  Online shopping impossible.  Keeping up with others would have involved long periods of delay and intimacy would have suffered.  Schooling would have been limited to what is in a book with no ready explanations or fun games to assist.   Doctor visits would h

I think we are in a time of transition.  There should be and will be a balance as things normalize once again but screens are here to stay.  Perhaps we are just concerned about change, change in the way we work, relate to others, conduct ourselves.  Who among us has not just gussied up from the waist up for a Zoom call, skipping a shower and matching socks?  We need to establish new norms of behavior.  We need to be more flexible and adaptable and accepting.

Schooling would have been limited to what is in a book with no ready explanations or fun games to assist.   Doctor visits would have been only by phone 

I think we are in a time of transition.  There should be and will be a balance as things normalize once again but screens are here to stay.  Perhaps we are just concerned about change, change in the way we work, relate to others, conduct ourselves.  Who among us has not just gussied up from the waist up for a Zoom call, skipping a shower and matching socks?  We need to establish new norms of behavior.  We need to be more flexible and adaptable and accepting.

How Worried Should We Be About Screen Time During the Pandemic?

The coronavirus pandemic ended the screen time debate: Screens won. We all now find ourselves on our screens for school, for work and for connecting with family and friends during this time of social distancing and increased isolation.

But should we be worried about this excessive screen use right now? Or should we finally get over it and embrace the benefits of our digital devices?

Remote work would have been mostly impossible for many.  Online shopping impossible.  Keeping up with others would have involved long periods of delay and intimacy would have suffered.  Schooling would have been limited to what is in a book with no ready explanations or fun games to assist.   Doctor visits would have been only by phone with no opportunity for

I think we are in a time of transition.  There should be and will be a balance as things normalize once again but screens are here to stay.  Perhaps we are just concerned about change, change in the way we work, relate to others, conduct ourselves.  Who among us has not just gussied up from the waist up for a Zoom call, skipping a shower and matching socks?  We need to establish new norms of behavior.  We need to be more flexible and adaptable and accepting.

The coronavirus pandemic ended the screen time debate: Screens won. We all now find ourselves on our screens for school, for work and for connecting with family and friends during this time of social distancing and increased isolation.

But should we be worried about this excessive screen use right now? Or should we finally get over it and embrace the benefits of our digital devices?

---

In my opinion, embrace it.  It has become a necessity so there is no point in having guilt, etc. about it.  At some point things will change and our behaviors will be more balanced.

Just think how up the creek without a paddle we would have been if we hadn't had the accessibility to screens and all the things they make possible.  Remote work would have been mostly impossible for many.  Online shopping impossible.  Keeping up with others would have involved long periods of delay and intimacy would have suffered.  Schooling would have been limited to what is in a book with no ready explanations or fun games to assist.   Doctor visits would have been only by phone with no opportunity for a more finely tuned di

I think we are in a time of transition.  There should be and will be a balance as things normalize once again but screens are here to stay.  Perhaps we are just concerned about change, change in the way we work, relate to others, conduct ourselves.  Who among us has not just gussied up from the waist up for a Zoom call, skipping a shower and matching socks?  We need to establish new norms of behavior.  We need to be more flexible and adaptable and accepting.

Remote work would have been mostly impossible for many.  Online shopping impossible.  Keeping up with others would have involved long periods of delay and intimacy would have suffered.  Schooling would have been limited to what is in a book with no ready explanations or fun games to assist.   Doctor visits would have been only by phone with no opportunity for a more finely tuned diagnosis in many instan

I think we are in a time of transition.  There should be and will be a balance as things normalize once again but screens are here to stay.  Perhaps we are just concerned about change, change in the way we work, relate to others, conduct ourselves.  Who among us has not just gussied up from the waist up for a Zoom call, skipping a shower and matching socks?  We need to establish new norms of behavior.  We need to be more flexible and adaptable and accepting.

Remote work would have been mostly impossible for many.  Online shopping impossible.  Keeping up with others would have involved long periods of delay and intimacy would have suffered.  Schooling would have been limited to what is in a book with no ready explanations or fun games to assist.   Doctor visits would have been only by phone with no opportunity for a more finely tuned diagnosis in many instances.

I think we are in a time of transition.  There should be and will be a balance as things normalize once again but screens are here to stay.  Perhaps we are just concerned about change, change in the way we work, relate to others, conduct ourselves.  Who among us has not just gussied up from the waist up for a Zoom call, skipping a shower and matching socks?  We need to establish new norms of behavior.  We need to be more flexible,  adaptable and accepting.

Instead of spe

But should we be worried about this excessive screen use right now? Or should we finally get over it and embrace the benefits of our digital devices?

---

In my opinion, embrace it.  It has become a necessity so there is no point in having guilt, etc. about it.  At some point things will change and our behaviors will be more balanced.

Just think how up the creek without a paddle we would have been if we hadn't had the accessibility to screens and all the things they make possible.  Remote work would have been mostly impossible for many.  Online shopping impossible.  Keeping up with others would have involved long periods of delay and intimacy would have suffered.  Schooling would have been limited to what is in a book with no ready explanations or fun games to assist.   Doctor visits would have been only by phone with no opportunity for a more finely tuned diagnosis in many instances.

I think we are in a time of transition.  There should be and will be a balance as things normalize once again but screens are here to stay.  Perhaps we are just concerned about change, change in the way we work, relate to others, conduct ourselves.  Who among us has not just gussied up from the waist up for a Zoom call, skipping a shower and matching socks?  We need to establish new norms of behavior.  We need to be more flexible,  adaptable and accepting.

Instead of spending our time bemoaning t

Schooling would have been limited to what is in a book with no ready explanations or fun games to assist.   Doctor visits would have been only by phone with no opportunity for a more finely tuned diagnosis in many instances.

I think we are in a time of transition.  There should be and will be a balance as things normalize once again but screens are here to stay.  Perhaps we are just concerned about change, change in the way we work, relate to others, conduct ourselves.  Who among us has not just gussied up from the waist up for a Zoom call, skipping a shower and matching socks?  We need to establish new norms of behavior.  We need to be more flexible,  adaptable and accepting.

Instead of spending our time bemoaning the lack of in-person ins

How Worried Should We Be About Screen Time During the Pandemic?

The coronavirus pandemic ended the screen time debate: Screens won. We all now find ourselves on our screens for school, for work and for connecting with family and friends during this time of social distancing and increased isolation.

But should we be worried about this excessive screen use right now? Or should we finally get over it and embrace the benefits of our digital devices?

---

In my opinion, embrace it.  It has become a necessity so there is no point in having guilt, etc. about it.  At some point things will change and our behaviors will be more balanced.

Doctor visits would have been only by phone with no opportunity for a more finely tuned diagnosis in many instances.

I think we are in a time of transition.  There should be and will be a balance as things normalize once again but screens are here to stay.  Perhaps we are just concerned about change, change in the way we work, relate to others, conduct ourselves.  Who among us has not just gussied up from the waist up for a Zoom call, skipping a shower and matching socks?  We need to establish new norms of behavior.  We need to be more flexible,  adaptable and accepting.

Instead of spending our time bemoaning the lack of in-person instruction we should be con

How Worried Should We Be About Screen Time During the Pandemic?

The coronavirus pandemic ended the screen time debate: Screens won. We all now find ourselves on our screens for school, for work and for connecting with family and friends during this time of social distancing and increased isolation.

But should we be worried about this excessive screen use right now? Or should we finally get over it and embrace the benefits of our digital devices?

---

In my opinion, embrace it.  It has become a necessity so there is no point in having guilt, etc. about it.  At some point things will change and our behaviors will be more balanced.

Just think how up the creek without a paddle we would have been if we hadn't had the accessibility to screens and all the things they make possible.  Remote work would have been mostly impossible for many.  Online shopping impossible.  Keeping up with others would have involved long periods of delay and intimacy would have suffered. Who among us has not just gussied up from the waist up for a Zoom call, skipping a shower and matching socks?  We need to establish new norms of behavior.  We need to be more flexible,  adaptable and accepting.

Instead of spending our time bemoaning the lack of in-person instruction we should be cons

Remote work would have been mostly impossible for many.  Online shopping impossible.  Keeping up with others would have involved long periods of delay and intimacy would have suffered.  Schooling would have been limited to what is in a book with no ready explanations or fun games to assist.   Doctor visits would have been only by phone with no opportunity for a more finely tuned diagnosis in many instances.

I think we are in a time of transition.  There should be and will be a balance as things normalize once again but screens are here to stay.  Perhaps we are just concerned about change, change in the way we work, relate to others, conduct ourselves.  Who among us has not just gussied up from the waist up for a Zoom call, skipping a shower and matching socks?  We need to establish new norms of behavior.  We need to be more flexible,  adaptable and accepting.

Instead of spending our time bemoaning the lack of in-person instruction we should be constructive and pro-activ

How Worried Should We Be About Screen Time During the Pandemic?

The coronavirus pandemic ended the screen time debate: Screens won. We all now find ourselves on our screens for school, for work and for connecting with family and friends during this time of social distancing and increased isolation.

But should we be worried about this excessive screen use right now? Or should we finally get over it and embrace the benefits of our digital devices?

---

In my opinion, embrace it.  It has become a necessity so there is no point in having guilt, etc. about it.  At some point things will change and our behaviors will be more balanced.

Just think how up the creek without a paddle we would have been if we hadn't had the accessibility to screens and all the things they make possible.  Remote work would have been mostly impossible for many.  Online shopping impossible.  Keeping up with others would have involved long periods of delay and intimacy would have suffered.  Schooling would have been limited to what is in a book with no ready explanations or fun games to assist.   Doctor visits would have been only by phone with no opportunity for a more finely tuned diagnosis in many instances.

I think we are in a time of transition.  There should be and will be a balance as things normalize once again but screens are here to stay.  Perhaps we are just concerned about change, change in the way we work, relate to others, conduct ourselves.  Who among us has not just gussied up from the waist up for a Zoom call, skipping a shower and matching socks?  We need to establish new norms of behavior.  We need to be more flexible,  adaptable and accepting.

Instead of spending our time bemoaning the lack of in-person instruction we should be constructive and pro-active in seeking to make dista

Remote work would have been mostly impossible for many.  Online shopping impossible.  Keeping up with others would have involved long periods of delay and intimacy would have suffered.  Schooling would have been limited to what is in a book with no ready explanations or fun games to assist.   Doctor visits would have been only by phone with no opportunity for a more finely tuned diagnosis in many instances.

I think we are in a time of transition.  There should be and will be a balance as things normalize once again but screens are here to stay.  Perhaps we are just concerned about change, change in the way we work, relate to others, conduct ourselves.  Who among us has not just gussied up from the waist up for a Zoom call, skipping a shower and matching socks?  We need to establish new norms of behavior.  We need to be more flexible,  adaptable and accepting.

Instead of spending our time bemoaning the lack of in-person instruction we should be constructive and pro-active in seeking to make distance learning work for al

How Worried Should We Be About Screen Time During the Pandemic?

The coronavirus pandemic ended the screen time debate: Screens won. We all now find ourselves on our screens for school, for work and for connecting with family and friends during this time of social distancing and increased isolation.

We need to be more flexible,  adaptable and accepting.

Schooling would have been limited to what is in a book with no ready explanations or fun games to assist.   Doctor visits would have been only by phone with no opportunity for a more finely tuned diagnosis in many instances.

I think we are in a time of transition.  There should be and will be a balance as things normalize once again but screens are here to stay.  Perhaps we are just concerned about change, change in the way we work, relate to others, conduct ourselves.  Who among us has not just gussied up from the waist up for a Zoom call, skipping a shower and matching socks?  We need to establish new norms of behavior.  We need to be more flexible,  adaptable and accepting.

Instead of spending our time bemoaning the lack of in-person instruction we should be constructive and pro-active in seeking to make distance learning work for all.  Many places in Au

How Worried Should We Be About Screen Time During the Pandemic?

The coronavirus pandemic ended the screen time debate: Screens won. We all now find ourselves on our screens for school, for work and for connecting with family and friends during this time of social distancing and increased isolation.

But should we be worried about this excessive screen use right now? Or should we finally get over it and embrace the benefits of our digital devices?

---

In my opinion, embrace it.  It has become a necessity so there is no point in having guilt, etc. about it.  At some point things will change and our behaviors will be more balanced.

We need to be more flexible,  adaptable and accepting.

Remote work would have been mostly impossible for many.  Online shopping impossible.  Keeping up with others would have involved long periods of delay and intimacy would have suffered.  Schooling would have been limited to what is in a book with no ready explanations or fun games to assist.   Doctor visits would have been only by phone with no opportunity for a more finely tuned diagnosis in many instances.

I think we are in a time of transition.  There should be and will be a balance as things normalize once again but screens are here to stay.  Perhaps we are just concerned about change, change in the way we work, relate to others, conduct ourselves.  Who among us has not just gussied up from the waist up for a Zoom call, skipping a shower and matching socks?  We need to establish new norms of behavior.  We need to be more flexible,  adaptable and accepting.

Instead of spending our time bemoaning the lack of in-person instruction we should be constructive and pro-active in seeking to make distance learning work for all.  Many places in Australia do their school

The coronavirus pandemic ended the screen time debate: Screens won. We all now find ourselves on our screens for school, for work and for connecting with family and friends during this time of social distancing and increased isolation.

But should we be worried about this excessive screen use right now? Or should we finally get over it and embrace the benefits of our digital devices?

---

In my opinion, embrace it.  It has become a necessity so there is no point in having guilt, etc. about it.  At some point things will change and our behaviors will be more balanced.

Just think how up the creek without a paddle we would have been if we hadn't had the accessibility to screens and all the things they make possible.  Remote work would have been mostly impossible for many.  Online shopping impossible.  Keeping up with others would have involved long periods of delay and intimacy would have suffered.  Schooling would have been limited to what is in a book with no ready explanations or fun games to assist.   Doctor visits would have been only by phone with no opportunity for a more finely tuned diagnosis in many instances.

I think we are in a time of transition.  There should be and will be a balance as things normalize once again but screens are here to stay.  Perhaps we are just concerned about change, change in the way we work, relate to others, conduct ourselves.  Who among us has not just gussied up from the waist up for a Zoom call, skipping a shower and matching socks?  We need to establish new norms of behavior.  We need to be more flexible,  adaptable and accepting.

Instead of spending our time bemoaning the lack of in-person instruction we should be constructive and pro-active in seeking to make distance learning work for all.  Many places in Australia do their schooling via radio and have fo

Schooling would have been limited to what is in a book with no ready explanations or fun games to assist.   Doctor visits would have been only by phone with no opportunity for a more finely tuned diagnosis in many instances.

I think we are in a time of transition.  There should be and will be a balance as things normalize once again but screens are here to stay.  Perhaps we are just concerned about change, change in the way we work, relate to others, conduct ourselves.  Who among us has not just gussied up from the waist up for a Zoom call, skipping a shower and matching socks?  We need to establish new norms of behavior.  We need to be more flexible,  adaptable and accepting.

Instead of spending our time bemoaning the lack of in-person instruction we should be constructive and pro-active in seeking to make distance learning work for all.  Many places in Australia do their schooling via radio and have for years, with screens i

How Worried Should We Be About Screen Time During the Pandemic?

The coronavirus pandemic ended the screen time debate: Screens won. We all now find ourselves on our screens for school, for work and for connecting with family and friends during this time of social distancing and increased isolation.

But should we be worried about this excessive screen use right now? Or should we finally get over it and embrace the benefits of our digital devices?

---

In my opinion, embrace it.  It has become a necessity so there is no point in having guilt, etc. about it.  At some point things will change and our behaviors will be more balanced.

How Worried Should We Be About Screen Time During the Pandemic?

The coronavirus pandemic ended the screen time debate: Screens won. We all now find ourselves on our screens for school, for work and for connecting with family and friends during this time of social distancing and increased isolation.

But should we be worried about this excessive screen use right now? Or should we finally get over it and embrace the benefits of our digital devices?

---

In my opinion, embrace it.  It has become a necessity so there is no point in having guilt, etc. about it.  At some point things will change and our behaviors will be more balanced.

Just think how up the creek without a paddle we would have been if we hadn't had the accessibility to screens and all the things they make possible.  Remote work would have been mostly impossible for many.  Online shopping impossible.  Keeping up with others would have involved long periods of delay and intimacy would have suffered.  Schooling would have been limited to what is in a book with no ready explanations or fun games to assist.   Doctor visits would have been only by phone with no opportunity for a more finely tuned diagnosis in many instances.

I think we are in a time of transition.  There should be and will be a balance as things normalize once again but screens are here to stay.  Perhaps we are just concerned about change, change in the way we work, relate to others, conduct ourselves.  Who among us has not just gussied up from the waist up for a Zoom call, skipping a shower and matching socks?  We need to establish new norms of behavior.  We need to be more flexible,  adaptable and accepting.

Instead of spending our time bemoaning the lack of in-person instruction we should be constructive and pro-active in seeking to make distance learning work for all.  Many places in Australia do their schooling via radio and have for years, with screens it's much better than tha

How Worried Should We Be About Screen Time During the Pandemic?

The coronavirus pandemic ended the screen time debate: Screens won. We all now find ourselves on our screens for school, for work and for connecting with family and friends during this time of social distancing and increased isolation.

But should we be worried about this excessive screen use right now? Or should we finally get over it and embrace the benefits of our digital devices?

---

In my opinion, embrace it.  It has become a necessity so there is no point in having guilt, etc. about it.  At some point things will change and our behaviors will be more balanced.

Just think how up the creek without a paddle we would have been if we hadn't had the accessibility to screens and all the things they make possible.  Remote work would have been mostly impossible for many.  Online shopping impossible.  Keeping up with others would have involved long periods of delay and intimacy would have suffered.  Schooling would have been limited to what is in a book with no ready explanations or fun games to assist.   Doctor visits would have been only by phone with no opportunity for a more finely tuned diagnosis in many instances.

I think we are in a time of transition.  There should be and will be a balance as things normalize once again but screens are here to stay. We need to be more flexible,  adaptable and accepting.

Instead of spending our time bemoaning the lack of in-person instruction we should be constructive and pro-active in seeking to make distance learning work for all.  Many places in Australia do their schooling via radio and have for years, with screens it's much better than that.  We just need to adapt

Remote work would have been mostly impossible for many.  Online shopping impossible.  Keeping up with others would have involved long periods of delay and intimacy would have suffered.  Schooling would have been limited to what is in a book with no ready explanations or fun games to assist.   Doctor visits would have been only by phone with no opportunity for a more finely tuned diagnosis in many instances.

I think we are in a time of transition.  There should be and will be a balance as things normalize once again but screens are here to stay.  Perhaps we are just concerned about change, change in the way we work, relate to others, conduct ourselves.  Who among us has not just gussied up from the waist up for a Zoom call, skipping a shower and matching socks?  We need to establish new norms of behavior.  We need to be more flexible,  adaptable and accepting.

Instead of spending our time bemoaning the lack of in-person instruction we should be constructive and pro-active in seeking to make distance learning work for all.  Many places in Australia do their schooling via radio and have for years, with screens it's much better than that.  We just need to adapt and get on w

How Worried Should We Be About Screen Time During the Pandemic?

The coronavirus pandemic ended the screen time debate: Screens won. We all now find ourselves on our screens for school, for work and for connecting with family and friends during this time of social distancing and increased isolation.

But should we be worried about this excessive screen use right now? Or should we finally get over it and embrace the benefits of our digital devices?

---

In my opinion, embrace it.  It has become a necessity so there is no point in having guilt, etc. about it.  At some point things will change and our behaviors will be more balanced.

Just think how up the creek without a paddle we would have been if we hadn't had the accessibility to screens and all the things they make possible.  Remote work would have been mostly impossible for many.  Online shopping impossible.  Keeping up with others would have involved long periods of delay and intimacy would have suffered.  Schooling would have been limited to what is in a book with no ready explanations or fun games to assist.   Doctor visits would have been only by phone with no opportunity for a more finely tuned diagnosis in many instances.

I think we are in a time of transition.  There should be and will be a balance as things normalize once again but screens are here to stay.  Perhaps we are just concerned about change, change in the way we work, relate to others, conduct ourselves.  Who among us has not just gussied up from the waist up for a Zoom call, skipping a shower and matching socks?  We need to establish new norms of behavior.  We need to be more flexible,  adaptable and accepting.

Instead of spending our time bemoaning the lack of in-person instruction we should be constructive and pro-active in seeking to make distance learning work for all. In my opinion, embrace it.  It has become a necessity so there is no point in having guilt, etc. about it.  At some point things will change and our behaviors will be more balanced.

Just think how up the creek without a paddle we would have been if we hadn't had the accessibility to screens and all the things they make possible.  Remote work would have been mostly impossible for many.  Online shopping impossible.  Keeping up with others would have involved long periods of delay and intimacy would have suffered.  Schooling would have been limited to what is in a book with no ready explanations or fun games to assist.   Doctor visits would have been only by phone with no opportunity for a more finely tuned diagnosis in many instances.

I think we are in a time of transition.  There should be and will be a balance as things normalize once again but screens are here to stay.  Perhaps we are just concerned about change, change in the way we work, relate to others, conduct ourselves.  Who among us has not just gussied up from the waist up for a Zoom call, skipping a shower and matching socks?  We need to establish new norms of behavior.  We need to be more flexible,  adaptable and accepting.

Instead of spending our time bemoaning the lack of in-person instruction we should be constructive and pro-active in seeking to make distance learning work for all.  Many places in Australia do their schooling via radio and have for years, with screens it's much better than that.  We just need to adapt and get on with it because I'm convinced screens are he

Remote work would have been mostly impossible for many.  Online shopping impossible.  Keeping up with others would have involved long periods of delay and intimacy would have suffered.  Schooling would have been limited to what is in a book with no ready explanations or fun games to assist.   Doctor visits would have been only by phone with no opportunity for a more finely tuned diagnosis in many instances.

I think we are in a time of transition.  There should be and will be a balance as things normalize once again but screens are here to stay.  Perhaps we are just concerned about change, change in the way we work, relate to others, conduct ourselves.  Who among us has not just gussied up from the waist up for a Zoom call, skipping a shower and matching socks?  We need to establish new norms of behavior.  We need to be more flexible,  adaptable and accepting.

Instead of spending our time bemoaning the lack of in-person instruction we should be constructive and pro-active in seeking to make distance learning work for all.  Many places in Australia do their schooling via radio and have for years, with screens it's much better than that.  We just need to adapt and get on with it because I'm convinced screens are here to stay very much pr
